ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned new editing software, how to develop a story and about the ethics of documentary filmmaking.
This was a wonderful class!! So interesting, and my peers were so interesting and had great topics and discussions throughout.

I created my first documentary! More than learning how to edit, how to use a camera, etc. I learned about the film industry and, at a high level, how to create a documentary (e.g. ask interview questions, film and editing work stream, etc.) the insight from the Professor as a director was awesome and gave me significant insight into the field. More than learning how to create a documentary at the detailed level, this class in my opinion is more fit for the aspiring director/producer.
I learned many aspects about how to create a documentary, from conception to execution.
Learned the processes of video production specifically for documentary film making. Also on how to not only talk and reference it but also how to practice the skills talked about.
I gained confidence using editing software and writing a story; I also learned the different elements that go into making a film.
Fundamental processes of documentary filmmaking and theory, as well as applying those theories and ideas to actual production was very helpful.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The biggest weakness of the class is the classroom and the length of the class. 4 hours in a windowless room is a long time. 

Professor Fisher was great and able to add her personal experience making documentary films to the class.
In addition to high level information about the subject, learning more about how to film and edit more, especially given that class times are long, would be helpful.

I think it was nicely structured but there was zero need for it to be a 4 hour block. We couldve just had more productive sessions in 2 hours even. By the time we passed two hours everyone was over it and feedback and discussion became stale.
It was strong in the ways we had guest speakers and different classes dedicated to specific areas of documentary making.

Strength:
- the projects (especially the final film) take a lot of time but they are really rewarding. It feels good to do something creative and share it with your classmates
- Professor Fisher is a successful filmmaker and she also brings in guests who are experts (e.g. a director and an editor) so you get a lot of exposure to the actual industry

Weaknesses:
- I wish the breadth of documentaries we talked about and watched was larger -- we mainly watched social/historical films. It would have been cool to watch a travel or culture documentary, for example.

- I wish we hadn't been assigned QCQ (question, comment, quote) homeowork while we were also completing our final projects. It wasn't bad at all though.

I think this course was really strong in applying theory and applying technical craft to an actual result, as well as connecting that result to an idea of what documentary film is supposed to achieve.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course. There is no prior experience needed and you feel great after finishing your own documentary.
I cannot say that I would recommend this course to other students because of how long the block is.
This course is amazing if you want to get start or even just take it for fun and for the purpose of trying out documentary filmmaking.
Yes! This class won't spoon feed you anything but, if you put into the time to make a good project, it will be awarding. Be ready to engage, though.
I would recommend this class to anyone interested in expression through the medium of film and with in interest in the ethics of documentary.
